## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
students_raw <- read_csv('../data/students_raw.csv')
students_raw

grade_codebook <- read_csv('../data/grade_codebook.csv')
grade_codebook
```

```{r}
students_raw_clean <- students_raw |> 
  clean_names() |> 
  mutate(school_name = case_when(school_name == 'lincoln elem' ~ 'Lincoln Elem',
                                 TRUE ~ school_name)) |> 
  mutate(ethn_cd = case_when(ethn_cd == 'HISP' ~ 'Hispanic',
                             ethn_cd == 'Hisp' ~ 'Hispanic', 
                             ethn_cd == 'ASIAN' ~ 'Asian',
                             ethn_cd == 'WHITE' ~ 'White',
                             TRUE ~ ethn_cd)) |> 
  drop_na()
  

students_raw_clean
```

```{r}
combo <-students_raw_clean |> 
  left_join(grade_codebook, by = 'grade_cd')

combo
```

Create a **bar chart** showing the **average attendance rate by grade** (using the grade label on the x-axis).

```{r}
attendance_grade <- combo |> 
  group_by(grade_label) |> 
  summarize(average_attend = mean(att_rate)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = grade_label, y= average_attend)) +
  geom_col()+
  labs(title = 'Average Attendance Rate by Grade', x = 'Grade Level', y= 'Attendance Rate') +
  theme_minimal()

attendance_grade
 
```

Using the cleaned and joined student data, create a **line plot** showing the **average test score by grade**, using the *grade label* (e.g., Grade 3, Grade 4, Grade 5) on the x-axis.

```{r}
combo
```

```{r}
line <- combo |>
  group_by(grade_label) |> 
  summarise(avg_score = mean(test_score)) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x=grade_label, y = avg_score, group =1 )) +
  geom_line()+
  labs(title = 'Average Score per Grade Level') +
  theme_minimal()

line
```
